Notes: On 16 may 2022, some jurisdictions have no covid-related health measures in schools. However, some provinces and territories continue to require masks and other covid-related health measures in schools â e.g., some Atlantic provinces. Some post-secondary institutions are offering classes and exams online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 1T fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures still applicable in schools in some jurisdictions and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See government of PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145709/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/newfoundland-and-labrador-to-drop-mandatory-masking-in-schools-on-may-24-1.5901841  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145945/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 23 may 2022, some provinces are approaching the end of mandates requiring masks and other covid-related health measures in elementary and secondary schools. Some post-secondary institutions are offering classes and exams online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 1T fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures still applicable in schools in some jurisdictions and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of NL and PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522170646/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/schools-children/schools/masks/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522164219/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145709/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/newfoundland-and-labrador-to-drop-mandatory-masking-in-schools-on-may-24-1.5901841  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 24 may 2022, the last four jurisdictions â Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon â previously requiring masks in elementary and secondary schools end their mandates â âall provinces in Canada have removed mask mandates in schoolsâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of NS, Yukon and PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103208/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/mask-mandates-end-in-all-atlantic-canadian-schools-but-health-officials-still-recommend-their-use-1.5916436  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103515/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20220519001  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522164219/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171554/https://yukon.ca/en/health-and-wellness/covid-19-information/k-12-school-guidelines-2021-22-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 30 may 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âprocedure for vaccine requirementâ remains in force until 1 June. âMemorial continues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âcontinues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. See Globe and Mail newspaper and MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-to-lift-its-covid-19-mask-mandate-for-provinces-public/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530170157/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/

On 1 june 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. At Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âMemorial suspended the requirement for masks on all campuses on June 1â¦ Memorial's procedure for vaccine requirement suspended on June 1 at 12:01 a.m. in alignment with the suspension of the NL Public Sector Policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools at any level and 0 now fits for unvaccinated students, who can now enter the post-secondary MUN campus âin alignment with the suspension of the [government of NL] Public Sector Policyâ. See Globe and Mail newspaper and MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-to-lift-its-covid-19-mask-mandate-for-provinces-public/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220602133007/www.mun.ca/covid19/

On 16 may 2022 the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to recommend: âStaying home and keeping away from others if you test positive or are experiencing any symptoms, even if mildâ. The  âany symptoms, even if mildâ component of this recommendation is broader and more prescriptive than previous advice at the end of 2021: âstay at home when you're sick â¦ Be prepared to stay at home if you have symptomsâ. Some jurisdictions are not following the national governmentâs recommendation and have ended isolation rules for covid-positive patients. However, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canadaâs recommendation is publicly available for all Canadians. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515205003/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html

On 16 may 2022, the government of Canada continues ârequiring full vaccination for Canadians boarding a commercial plane or train for travel to domestic and international destinationsâ. A prominent professor of medicine urges the government to âreconsider [as] The justification behind vaccine mandates is that they help prevent transmission. But this does not seem to be the case any longer, with the Omicron variantâ. He cites equity grounds and several other arguments against the national governmentâs vaccine mandate for domestic air and rail travelers. See Globe and Mail newspaper, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220514162340/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-logic-behind-vaccine-mandates-for-travellers-no-longer-holds/

The editorial board of a leading newspaper argues that the government âneeds to explain whyâ. On 30 may 2022, Canada remains open to entry by non-citizens, but only those who meet the following requirements: âyou must qualify as a fully vaccinated traveller to enter Canada, unless you have a job in 1 of the following categories: Agricultural or food processing worker; Marine crew member; Make medical deliveries; Work with medical equipment or devicesâ. In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors subject to screening requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220530083940/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/visitors-workers-students

In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors subject to screening requirements. On 16 may 2022, the government of Canada continues with a ânational public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual risk management. While some sub-national government approaches are no longer consistent with the national governmentâs information campaign, 2G still warranted due to the national scope of Government of Canada public outreach efforts. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515164541/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

On 23 may 2022, the government of Canada continues with a ânational public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual risk management. While some sub-national government approaches are no longer consistent with the national governmentâs information campaign, 2G still warranted due to the national scope of Government of Canada public outreach efforts. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521163737/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

On 16 may 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow and other rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. A prominent health policy reporter states: âTo date, there have been 3.8 million recorded cases in Canada (the true number is certainly much higher because weâve largely given up on testing.)â See Government of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515162357/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220514165219/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-40000-covid-19-deaths/

On 23 may 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. In Canadaâs most populous province: âPublic Health Ontario noted that testing eligibility is currently restricted to high-risk populations â¦Ontario reported 1,412 new infections of COVID-19 Friday [out of a total population of almost 15 million], although PCR testing is limited to certain groups. The scientific director of Ontarioâs panel of COVID-19 advisers has said multiplying the daily case count by 10 would give a more accurate picture.â See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521170744/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521170024/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-presence-of-ba220-in-ontario-doesnt-warrant-significant-concern/

On 30 may 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. In Canadaâs most populous province of Ontario: âDue to testing limitations, officials say the actual number of daily new cases is likely far higher than the figure reported.â See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529161107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529160646/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-covid-update-saturday-may-28-2022-1.6469644

On 6 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: ârapid antigen tests have replaced wide-scale PCR tests; fewer people are now eligible for PCR testing across the country after high demand for testing during the Omicron wave overwhelmed testing centresâ¦an infectious disease physician at the University of Alberta Hospital in Edmonton, saidâ¦ "the public does not have a way of being able to confirm they actually have COVID â¦â she noted that rapid tests have become less reliable when it comes to Omicronâ. See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605105043/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220603140724/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/rapid-test-cease-2022-phac-1.6475870

See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605105043/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220614104939/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/technology/article-ottawa-expected-to-shut-down-national-covid-19-contact-tracing-app/

On 16 may 2022, government of Canada advises that when individuals âtest positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in most jurisdictions to deal with high case numbers. In most cases, contact tracing responsibility is up to individuals who are symptomatic and/or have tested positive. In Canadaâs most populous province, Ontario: âIf you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have tested positive, tell your close contacts that they have been exposedâ¦ Informing your contact will help stop the spread of the virus. Give them the link to this webpage, ontario.ca/exposed, so they can protect themselves and their contacts.â See Governments of Canada and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515162357/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515162630/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/exposed

Approved COVID-19 vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen, AstraZeneca (no longer recommended), Novavax, Medicago Cofifenz. On 16 may 2022, in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): âTemporary restrictions to visitation/attendance are in place at all provincially operated acute care facilities, treatment facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homesâ¦ Each patient/resident can have up to two visitors at a timeâ. NL may be the last Canadian jurisdiction with 2 = narrow restrictions in place regardless of visitor vaccination status. In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516144343/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145007/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions

On 23 may 2022, in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): âTemporary restrictions to visitation/attendance are in place at all provincially operated acute care facilities, treatment facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homesâ¦ Each patient/resident can have up to two visitors at a timeâ. Other provinces and territories have only recommended guidance for visitors regardless of vaccination status â e.g., New Brunswick (NB). In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522165408/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522165451/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220512111526/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

On 30 may 2022, in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): âTemporary restrictions to visitation/attendance are in place at all provincially operated acute care facilities, treatment facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homesâ¦ Each patient/resident can have up to two visitors at a timeâ. The vaccine mandate continues for staff including âVolunteers and hairdressersâ, but does not apply to visitors. Some NL facilities have limited visitors to 1, which still fits the definition of â2 = narrow restrictionsâ. Other provinces and territories have â1 = recommended guidanceâ rules for visitors regardless of vaccination status â e.g., New Brunswick (NB). In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530145808/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530144740/https://www.westernhealth.nl.ca/current-visitor-restrictions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530150631/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530181759/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

Some NL facilities limit visitors to 1 person, which still fits the definition of â2 = narrow restrictionsâ. Other provinces and territories have â1 = recommended guidanceâ rules for visitors regardless of vaccination status â e.g., New Brunswick (NB). In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220602173114/www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606152104/https://www.centralhealth.nl.ca/news-and-advisories  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606152444/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530181759/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

On June 12, 2022, the US changed its requirement for negative tests.     "As of 12:01AM ET on June 12, 2022, CDC will no longer require air passengers traveling from a foreign country to the United States to show a negative COVID-19 viral test or documentation of recovery from COVID-19 before they board their flight. For more information, see Rescission: Requirement for Negative Pre-Departure COVID-19 Test Result or Documentation of Recovery from COVID-19 for all Airline or Other Aircraft Passengers Arriving into the United States from Any Foreign Country."    However, this does not result in a change in stringency level as (1) international passengers are still required to be vaccinated and (2) vaccination check is considered a form of screening.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220612074246/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel/index.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220613044024/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/proof-of-vaccination.html

Per the USA government guidance on employment benefits, "The federal government allowed states to change their laws to provide COVID-19 unemployment benefits for people whose jobs have been affected by the coronavirus pandemic."    See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605014140/https://www.usa.gov/unemployment
Debt and contract relief is not being provided at the federal level.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220611182127/https://www.usa.gov/help-with-bills
The CDC still maintains a robust public information campaign.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612161104/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html
